header.title: Kindoki: A Manual of African Witchcraft and Brujeria
header.category: Occultism, African Traditional Religions, Necromancy, Witchcraft, Brujeria

central_thesis: This manual presents Kindoki and Brujeria as a distinct, non-religious, power-focused form of African-based witchcraft, centered on establishing a direct working relationship with earth-bound spirits of the dead (muertos) through consecrated fetishes, ritualized material components (palos), and the propitiation of crossroads deities like Exu, for practical, often aggressive, magical outcomes unconstrained by conventional morality.

structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces Kindoki and Brujeria as authentic African and Latino-based witchcraft, explicitly distinguishing it from modern Wicca and conventional religions. It emphasizes that true witchcraft cannot be rationally codified, operates outside societal norms, and is often seen as synonymous with criminal activity. Kindoki is defined as both necromantic magic and an innate power, resembling the 'evil eye' in its ability to unintentionally curse. It notes Kindoki's superficial resemblance to Palo but asserts its true alignment with Latin American Brujeria, characterized by its practical, power-focused, and morally unbound nature.

This section delves into the archetypal understanding of witches and the enduring belief in witchcraft in Africa, highlighting instances of persecution. It posits that certain individuals possess an innate ability to attract and channel an 'unknown force,' which, if refined, becomes a 'defined, refined talent.' The author identifies repetitive, unusual dreams involving elemental beings or spirits of the dead as a primary indicator of a natural witch. It clarifies that Kindoki, as practiced by some Paleros, is strictly sorcery and necromancy, focused on creating 'haunted fetishes' rather than religious observance.

This chapter defines a Kindoki fetish as a receptacle created to house a spirit of the dead (muerto), distinct from a Palo Prenda which is dedicated to a major spirit of that religion. It explains that all fetish ingredients possess 'radiations, memories, and a living spirit,' used to channel power and allow the spirit to access essential energies. The heart of the Kindoki fetish, ideally a human skull, is the spiritual and material anchor for communication. The construction involves making treaties and offerings to spirits, with a focus on specific materials like earth from sacred sites, animal remnants, and 'palos,' which are discussed in detail. Various housing options for the fetish are explored, including iron cauldrons, ceramic pots, gourds, and cloth bags.

This section provides a detailed list and description of various 'palos' (sacred woods or plants) used in Kindoki and Brujeria, outlining their individual magical properties and uses. Each palo is presented with its scientific name and common associations, such as Palo de Ceiba (most sacred, for good and evil), Palo Cedro (spiritual center), Palo Diablo (aggression, war), Palo Dagame (warding, protection), Palo Ramon (harnessing spiritual forces), Palo Dulce (domination, lust), Palo Caja (punishment, occult warfare), Palo Santo (domination, spiritual atmosphere), Palo de los Muertos (ancestors, divine justice), Palo Pino (sickness, analytical abilities), Palo Hueso (wealth, money attraction), Palo una de Gato (sinister witchcraft, curses), Palo Cocuyo (weather control, magnifying intent), Palo Blanco (spiritual baths), Palo Bronco (protection, walking sticks), Palo Caballero (reverse black magic), Palo Cenizo (stability, balance), Palo Moro (luck, love), Palo Amargo (overcoming negativity, healing), Palo Mulatto (works of witchcraft), Palo Rompe Hueso (breaks barriers, black magic attacks), Palo Yaya (reverses negativity), Palo Tengue (protects, strengthens), Palo Yamao (summoning staffs), Palo Moruru (aborts betrayal), Palo Muerto (killing magic), Palo Cuaba (manipulating minds, black magic), Palo Abre Camino (opens/closes opportunity), Palo Justica (justice system), Palo Jabon (cleanse, purify), Palo Jeringa (seduction, lust), Palo Amansa Guapo (subdues, faithfulness), Palo Comito (keeps things hidden), Palo Negro (overcomes obstacles), Palo Canpeche (dispels enchantments), Palo Jobovan (justice system), Palo Malambo (black magic magnet), Palo Tocino (occult warfare), Palo Guaramo (wards unwanted spirits), Palo Guama (open gates to Hell), Palo Guasimo (prevents gossip), Palo Vencedor (battle, masculine Mpungo Prendas), Palo Guinda (dark witchcraft, dominating). Each entry specifies its use in charms, spells, and connection to spirits or Mpungos.

This chapter emphasizes the crucial role of Exu (also known as Ellegua, Eshu, Met Kalfu, Papa Legba) in African-based witchcraft, identifying him as the lord of the crossroads and owner of all doorways. It stresses that no act of witchcraft is effective without first consulting and propitiating Exu. The text provides initial steps for developing a relationship with Exu through simple offerings like coconut, candles, pennies, and cigars at crossroads or the home’s front door. It acknowledges different manifestations across traditions (Santeria, Candomble, Palo) and the option of purchasing Exu statues for altars, while cautioning against fabricating one's own Exu due to inherent secrets, suggesting instead to serve him at his natural abodes if a personal Exu is not obtained.

This section details methods for communicating with Kindoki spirits. Dreams (Ndozi) are highlighted as the most effective 'bridges of communication,' allowing spirits to convey complex instructions. Other methods include meditation, 'fetish type of telescope' (scrying horn), coconut divination (Chamalongo/Obi), and cowrie shell divination (Nkobo). The process for coconut divination is explained, involving asking permission, preparing rinds, invoking the spirit, and interpreting patterns. A horn from a horned animal is used to tap the fetish and arouse the spirit within. The importance of establishing a strong relationship with the dead through treaties and regular interaction is stressed.

This chapter provides practical instructions for various 'trabajos' (spells) to be performed with the Kindoki fetish. It begins by advising practitioners to always seek the fetish spirit's consent before a working and to provide offerings (coffee, cigar, fruit, rum) upon successful completion. Spells include: 'To Destroy an Individual' (onion, rusty nails, black candle, salt, chili powder, Black Arts oil, cemetery burial), 'To Dominate an Individual’s Mind' (Palo Una de Gato, figure candle, pins, dirt, masonry jar, domination oil, red candles), 'To Separate Lovers or Friends' (chili powder, separation powder, animal fur, black figure candles, Palo Muerto powder, bone powder, ritual separation), 'To Make an Individual Sick' (black candles, jar, Palo Pino, Palo Malatto, earthworms, puddle water, rum, grave burial), 'Talisman to Draw Money' (Palo Hueso, threads, dollar bill, various herbs/powders, oil, silver coin, mojo bag, green candle), 'Spell to Cause Crossed Conditions' (small bottle, mercury, red palm oil, rum, hot peppers, red candle, crossroads smashing), 'Kindoki Oil Lamp for Destruction' (hollow gourd, dried venomous spiders, rooster claws, dead crow, bat, birch bark, various Palo powders, olive oil, wicks, cemetery burial), 'Zombie Powder' (powdered sage, damiana, human bone, cemetery earth, black coffee, Palo Santo, bull horn, toad, cemetery consecration), and 'Potent Wealth Drawing Powder' (Palo Hueso, Palo Namo, Cascarillia, precipitate powder, Herba Buena, Parasio herb, pumpkin seeds). Each spell lists materials and step-by-step instructions for execution.

key_concepts.definition: A form of African-based necromantic magic and naturally occurring power, comparable to Latin American brujeria. It operates outside conventional religious frameworks, focusing on direct power and results, often involving communication with the dead and spirits for various ends, including both constructive and destructive purposes. It is seen as a potent, non-rational expression of witchcraft.

Simply witchcraft, as understood in African and Latino-based cultures. It is devoid of religious dogma, codified systems of morality, or mysticism in the conventional sense. Brujeria is employed by witches based on personal need and desire, rather than altruistic systems of morals.

A spirit of the dead that can be acquired from a witch to serve as a familiar. It dwells in a fetish (e.g., plaited sansevieria resembling a snake) and is haunted by spirits nesting by rivers. The mulombe can perform acts of witchcraft for its owner, including bringing misfortune or vampirizing the shadow (ghost body) of a victim to create new mulombes.

A consecrated receptacle, purposely constructed to house a spirit of the dead (muerto) or an earth-bound spirit. It is filled with various ingredients (earths, animal remnants, palos, crystalline stones) which possess energetic memories and vibrations. The fetish serves as a spiritual and material anchor for the residing spirit and the sorcerer's communication and workings. Its construction involves making pacts and providing regular offerings, often including blood, for the spirit's loyalty and power.

Sacred woods or branches (e.g., Ceiba, Diablo, Santo) used as essential material components in Kindoki and Brujeria practices. Each palo possesses unique energetic properties ('vibrations') and is associated with specific magical functions (e.g., protection, domination, aggression, healing). They are often powdered or used to create tinctures and are collected with respect and ritual, forming crucial parts of fetishes and spellcraft.

A powerful spirit, also known as Ellegua, Eshu, Met Kalfu, Papa Legba, or Orixa Exu, originating from Western Africa. Exu is the Lord of the Crossroads, controlling doorways and the intersection of worlds. In Kindoki and Brujeria, Exu must be propitiated and consulted before any magical working can be effective, as he controls all energy and can transmute it to conform to the sorcerer's will. He is revered and feared for his power.

A term for 'dreaming' that also describes the spirit world and the swift, far-reaching movement of spirits. Dreams are considered primary bridges of communication between the witch and their Kindoki fetish spirit, often conveying complex instructions and insights for magical workings.

A simple and effective method of divination using four pieces of coconut rind. After propitiating the Orisha Obi for permission, the rinds are cast, and their patterns (e.g., Alafia, Etawa, Eyife, Okana, Oyekun) are interpreted to provide direct answers from the spirits. It is considered a respectful way to communicate, especially with the Kindoki fetish spirit.

practical_system.description: The practical system of Kindoki and Brujeria is a form of necromantic sorcery centered on a personal 'Kindoki fetish' which serves as a spiritual vessel for an earth-bound spirit of the dead ('muerto'). The fetish is constructed through a precise ritual involving the collection of various 'ingredients' (earths from specific locations, animal parts, human remnants, 'palos' or sacred woods/plants, crystals) that imbue it with energetic memories and access to elemental forces. A crucial element is making 'treaties' and providing regular 'feedings' (including blood libations) to secure the spirit's loyalty and power. All workings must begin with the propitiation of Exu, the Lord of the Crossroads, who is essential for opening and closing spiritual pathways. Communication with the fetish spirit is primarily achieved through 'Ndozi' (dreams), supplemented by coconut ('Obi' or 'Chamalongo') or cowrie shell ('nkobo') divination, and the ceremonial tapping of a 'spirit calling horn'. The magic is highly results-oriented, designed for personal needs and desires, including destructive or dominating outcomes, and explicitly operates outside of religious or moral strictures.
tools: Palos (Ceiba, Cedro, Diablo, Dagame, Ramon, Dulce, Caja, Santo, de los Muertos, Pino, Hueso, Una de Gato, Cocuyo, Blanco, Bronco, Caballero, Cenizo, Moro, Amargo, Mulatto, Rompe Hueso, Yaya, Tengue, Yamao, Moruru, Muerto, Cuaba, Abre Camino, Justica, Jabon, Jeringa, Amansa Guapo, Comito, Negro, Canpeche, Jobovan, Malambo, Tocino, Guaramo, Guama, Guasimo, Vencedor, Guinda)
Offerings: Coconut, rum, cigars, honey, pennies, black coffee, fruit, animal blood (chicken)
Candles (black, red, green, figure candles of appropriate sex, 7-day glass candles)
Spirit calling horn (deer antler, bull horn)
Divination tools: Coconut rinds, cowrie shells
Containers: Masonry jars, small bottles, cauldrons/pots, hollow gourds, small metal cauldrons

Magical powders: Chili powder, separation powder, black precipitate powder, Palo Muerto powder, powdered bone, powdered cat fur, powdered dog fur, powdered bull horn, powdered sage, powdered damiana, powdered Palo Santo, powdered toad, powdered Palo Namo, Cascarillia, powdered Herba Buena, powdered Parasio herb, powdered pumpkin seeds
Oils: Black Arts oil, domination oil, money drawing oil, red palm oil, olive oil

Other items: Rusty nails, red thread, pins, pictures/names of targets, small mirrors, Indian arrowheads, large stones, railroad spikes, human bones/skull (optional but recommended for fetish), animal remnants, black/red cloth, mojo bags, floating oil wicks, mercury (just a drop), small hot red peppers, earthworms, water from a puddle on a dirty street, silver dollar coin
rituals: Constructing a Kindoki Fetish: Involves choosing a spirit through divination, collecting materials from specific locations (cemeteries, crossroads, abandoned houses, forests), making treaties with spirits of the locality, preparing a vessel (cauldron, gourd), placing the spirit rock, layering ingredients, burying the fetish for three days, and then 'resurrecting' it. Final consecration involves an invocation, sacrifice of dark-colored chicken's blood, rum, cigar smoke, honey, and feathers.

Propitiating Exu: Initiated by offering a coconut and red, black, or white candle at the home's front door. After the candle burns out, the coconut, 21 pennies, and a lit cigar are taken to a crossroads and left for Exu.

Spirit Communication via Dreams: Achieved by lighting a candle, spraying rum, and blowing cigar smoke onto the Kindoki fetish before sleeping in the same room, paying attention to visions and spiritual turbulence.

Coconut Divination (Obi/Chamalongo): Breaking a coconut while saying 'ago Obi', cutting rinds into four pieces, holding them in hand, invoking the fetish spirit with rum and cigar smoke, sprinkling fresh water, asking a question, and dropping the rinds to interpret the resulting pattern (Alafia, Etawa, Eyife, Okana, Oyekun).

Cowrie Shell Divination (Nkobo): Similar to coconut divination, using four cowrie shells with rounded backs filed down to lay flat. Shells are washed in river water, fed with the fetish, and stored in a cloth bag within the fetish.

To Destroy an Individual: Onion hollowed out, target's picture/name inserted, sealed with rusty nails, black candle inscribed with name placed on top. Onion is sprayed with rum and cigar smoke. Fetish is invigorated with rum/cigar smoke. Candle burned 1/3 down for three nights while tapping fetish with horn and calling for destruction. Onion then left at cemetery gates with nine pennies.

To Dominate an Individual's Mind: Black figure candle of appropriate sex inscribed with target's name, anointed with domination oil. Palo Una de Gato tied to candle with red thread. Nine pins inserted into eyes, head, heart. Dirt from target's path, figure, rum, black precipitate powder, domination oil added to a masonry jar and sealed. Jar placed before fetish, red candles burned on top daily for eight days, evoking the spirit with a horn. Jar can be buried at the Kindoki spirit's grave for indefinite domination, or contents removed and burned for temporary effect.

To Separate Lovers or Friends: Black figure candles (two) inscribed with names, placed on a tray over pictures/names, facing away. Chili powder, separation powder, pulverized bone, Palo Muerto powder, pulverized cat/dog fur sprinkled. Candles lit, fetish tapped, then snuffed and moved apart incrementally over eight nights, a line of powder separating them. Remnants buried where individuals frequent.

To Make an Individual Sick: Target's picture in a large-mouthed jar. Dry ingredients (Palo Pino, Palo Malatto), dirty puddle water, thirteen earthworms, and rum added. Jar covered, placed before fetish. Black candle lit on top, incantations to sicken. Repeated for nine days. Jar and candle stubs buried in a cemetery over a grave. Spell broken only by skilled sorcerer, priest, or shaman.

Talisman to Draw Money: Palo Hueso wrapped with a two-dollar bill and nine different colored threads. Ends dipped in melted wax to seal. Placed in a glass with money drawing oil. Powdered Palo Namo and human bone sprinkled. Left for three days. Transferred to a green mojo bag with herbal ingredients and a silver dollar coin. Cigar smoke/rum blown into bag and onto fetish. Amulet hung in fetish, then by front door, and refreshed with oils/powders.

Spell to Cause Crossed Conditions: Target's picture/name (nine times) smeared with hot peppers, placed in a small bottle with mercury, red palm oil, and rum. Bottle sealed, placed before Kindoki fetish and Exu image. Small red candle lit. At midnight, bottle is smashed at a deserted crossroads, and the area is immediately left.

Kindoki Oil Lamp for Destruction: Ingredients (dried venomous spiders, rooster claws, dead crow, bat, birch bark, Palo powders) incinerated outdoors to ashes. Ashes placed in a hollow gourd. Black plate and small black bowl on top. Bowl filled with olive oil, target's picture at bottom. Floating wick lit. Lamp burned before fetish for three days, tapping fetish with horn and calling for destruction. Picture and ashes wrapped in black cloth, buried in a cemetery over a grave with nine pennies at the gate.

Zombie Powder: Powdered sage, damiana, human bone, earth from nine cemeteries, black coffee, Palo Santo, bull horn, and toad mixed together on a moonless night in a cemetery. Placed on victim's photo, black candle burned over it on a small plate to magically enslave. Also, placed over the victim's threshold.

Potent Wealth Drawing Powder: Powdered Palo Hueso, Palo Namo, Cascarillia, green/yellow precipitate powder, Herba Buena, Parasio herb, and pumpkin seeds mixed. Rubbed on hands before gambling, placed in a mojo bag, or sprinkled on client's pictures or for others in money matters.

relevant_quotes.text: There is very little that has been written on the subject of authentic African witchcraft, as the essence of true witchcraft cannot be codified or transmitted in a wholly rational manner. Witchcraft or brujeria as it is understood by African and Latino based cultures around the world, is not synonymous with religion or mysticism in the conventional sense.

Kindoki, being a term that is comparable to Latin American brujeria, is both a kind of African based necromantic magic, as well as a naturally occurring power displayed by a select type of individual.
Brujeria and Kindoki may be employed by any witch for whatever reason they want, and this purpose is based on personal need and desire rather than some abstract altruistic system of morals.
The African witch is considered an individual that lives outside of societal norm, and the witchcraft that they engage in is considered synonymous with criminal activity.

A mulombe, being a spirit of the dead, can perform acts of witchcraft for the owner or bring misfortune to anyone that their owner so desires. If the owner wants to attack an individual, the mulombe can be sent into the body of a victim. The shadow (ghost body) of a mulombe's victim is devoured/vampirized, killing the victim and part of the energy is reshaped into another mulombe to serve its owner, so the mulombe multiplies.

A Kindoki fetish that houses a muerto can differ from a fetish that contains a spirit elemental or familiar spirit. The earth bound dead are everywhere in the invisible realm and will readily respond to the witch if you simply give them some time and attention.

In most traditions, no act of witchcraft can truly be effective if Exu is not consulted or given a small symbolic sacrifice first. He is the owner of all Doorways, and as such he is the spirit that can open or close them depending upon his will.

Afefe Ogo says ".... true magical energy is derived from the individual witch's creative process and their connection with those forces that they have developed relationships with" and in Kindoki the reader will learn to wield potent methods that indeed foster such a connection with those 'forces' that have helped Magicians / Sorcerers / Witches / Shaman apply their magical energies for thousands of years.

critical_analysis.relevance: This manual offers a unique and direct perspective on African-based necromantic witchcraft, distinguishing it from popular New Age interpretations and even from more structured Afro-Caribbean religions like Palo, despite shared terminology. Its explicit focus on 'true witchcraft' as a non-religious, power-driven practice, unburdened by conventional morality, provides an operative framework for practitioners interested in direct engagement with spirits of the dead and crossroads deities. The detailed instructions for fetish construction, material collection ('palos'), and specific spellcraft fill a niche in occult literature that often lacks explicit, culturally-grounded practical manuals for such intense forms of magic. The text's emphasis on dreams and direct communication with spirits aligns with older grimoire traditions and spirit-contact practices, making it relevant for those exploring results-oriented magic beyond theoretical esotericism.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is primarily practitioners of necromantic magic, brujeria, and African-based witchcraft, particularly those with an interest in the operative aspects of Palo-derived systems but who seek a less dogmatic, more sorcery-focused approach. It appeals to individuals who are unconcerned with conventional moral frameworks in their magical pursuits and are prepared for direct, often aggressive, engagement with earth-bound spirits and deities like Exu. The book explicitly states it is not for practitioners of Wicca or those seeking a conventional religious path, but rather for those drawn to the raw, power-centric energies of traditional witchcraft and spirit work.
